channel.title: The Great Gatsby Notes
channel.generator: Webpage HTML Export plugin for Obsidian

item.title: Mrs. Wilson's Dog
item.description:
Animal
Tom buys this "Brown wash-rag[1] of a Black" dog for Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle) for 10 dollars during the Taxi ride pg. 44
Of unknown breed, part airedale, has startling White feet [2]
The dog may not have had a bath or a trim in a long time making it look like a wash-rag↩︎
The dog could represent innocence as it has yet to step foot into anything yet.↩︎

item.title: Mrs. Wilson's Brown Dress
item.description:
"She had changed her dress to a Brown figured mulin..." [1]
Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle)
A more neutral tone to her other two dresses she has worn. Not welcoming, not demanding, just neutral↩︎

item.title: The West
item.description:
Nick came from the west
Daisy asks Nick about a rumor of him engaged to a girl out west
Nick went East to escape the rumors from the west [1]
Is Nick running from something? ↩︎

item.title: Daisy's baby
item.description:
Daisy's baby she talks about in The Buchanans mansion two years old
Daisy hopes the baby girl will be a "beautiful little fool" pg. 32 [1]
It would be better to live ignorantly in bliss than understand what it happening and what might happen. This could also be what turned Daisy into a cynic↩︎

item.title: Miss Baker
item.description:
Characters
Lives in East Egg with the other The Buchanans
Miss Baker's Grey eye's[1]
Miss Baker mention's going to Chicago pg. 27
Miss Baker's "autumn-leaf Yellow of her hair" [2]
Her eyes could be taken as cold, calculating, a stone slate↩︎
Yellow is a good contrast to her grey eyes.↩︎

item.title: The Rise of the Coloured Empires
item.description:
Written by a man named Goddard
Mentioned at the Dinner Scene on pg. 26
"The idea is if we don't look out the white race will be--- will be utterly submerged." [1]
"Great Replacement Theory"↩︎
item.guid: Characters/The Buchanan's/Tom/The Rise of the Coloured Empires.md

item.title: Tom
item.description:
Characters
Lives in East Egg with the other The Buchanans "two shining arrogant eyes" pg.18 "always leaning aggressively forwards" pg.18 "gruff husky tenor" voice pg.18
He is married to Daisy pg. 25
Tom Causing Harm is not a rare thing[1]
Tom being violence combined with his "arrogant eyes" and "aggressive leaning" shows that he's more inclined to wrestle for control of a situation that talk about it↩︎

item.title: The Buchanans
item.description:
Characters
The Buchanans consist of Tom Miss Baker Daisy

item.title: Catherine
item.description:
Characters
Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle)'s sister
"Solid sticky bob of Red[1] hair and a complexion powdered milky White"
Bright, stands out, unique, power, wealth↩︎

item.title: Doctor T. J. Eckleburg
item.description:
Characters
His eyes are Blue and gigantic pg. 39 [1]
Has a pair of enormous Yellow spectacles [2]
Blue could mean clarity or coldness while it being gigantic shows that whatever the blue represents is enlarged↩︎
More yellow in the Valley of Ashes. Another thing to contrast the dingy environment. Bright, nice, helpful↩︎

item.title: Mrs. Wilson's apartment
item.description:
Locations
The apartment where Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle) lives. "The apartment was on the top floor---a small living room, a small dining room, a small bedroom and a bath." pg. 46The living room was taken over by a set a tapestried furniture way to large for it.
Tom gets a bottle of whiskey from a locked bureau door
Nick says he's only been drunk twice in his life, and the second time was "that afternoon" at the apartment. Then we went to buy cigarettes from a nearby corner store.
More guests arrive, first was Catherine, Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle)'s sister. Next was Mr. McKee and Mr. McKee.
Mr. McKee had just shaved "for there was a White[1] spot of lather on his cheekbone." pg. 48
Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle) had changed into a Cream[2] colored chiffon dress. The change of dress also had a change of personality. The intense vitality turned into impressive hauteur.
They start to talk about Mr. Gatsby. Mr. McKee went to one of Mr. Gatsby parties about a month ago.
They say Mr. Gatsby is a nephew or a cousin of Kaiser Wilhelm. Catherine claims she scared of Mr. Gatsby
It is revealed that Tom and Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle) can stand their current marriages. They claim Tom can't get a divorce because Daisy is Catholic. Nick knows that Daisy isn't catholic.
"The late afternoon sky bloomed in the window for a moment like the Blue honey[3] of the Mediterranean," pg. 55
they start to talk about George B. Wilson and how he borrowed someone's best suit instead of getting his own.
"yet high over the city our line of Yellow windows[4] must have contributed their share..." pg. 56
Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle) pulls aside Nick and tells him the story of how she and Tom met. It was on a train. She couldn't stop looking at Tom who was wearing a dress suit, white[5] shirt, and patent leather shoes.
Mrs. McKee plans to buy a list of things tomorrow, one of them being a Black[6] silk bow for her mother's grave
It was nine o'clock and people were falling asleep. Tom and Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle) argued over her right to say Daisy's name. Tom breaks her nose in a short deft movement. There were bloody Red[7] towels upon the bathroom floor.
Mr. McKee wakes up to the wailing of Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle) and walks out of the apartment. nick follows him.
A forgetful innocence↩︎
Compared to her dark blue outfit from the garage, the cream outfit seems less hostile and more welcoming and warm.↩︎
The blue honey of the Mediterranean could be seen as the slow rolling deep blue wave. The ocean is so expansive the waves seem to be moving like honey.↩︎
Yellow lights piecing through the ashen grey sky onto the streets below. Its like a lighthouse but instead of warning about the shoreline, its proclaiming to the people on the street that people are gathering in there.↩︎
White in this context can be seen as clean, neat, and strong↩︎
Represents death, decay, emptiness, a void↩︎
Red can mean anger or danger, blood red in particular shows more urgency and violence↩︎

item.title: Valley of Ashes
item.description:
"Where ashes grow like wheat into ridges" pg. 38 Between West Egg and New York
The air is thick with Grey[1] ash and covers everything in it like a perpetual winter
On one side is a small river with a drawbridge. Because of the drawbridges delay Nick got to meet Tom's woman in New York
Tom and Nick took a train to New York they got off the train and walked along the road under Doctor T. J. Eckleburg persistent stare pg. 40
The only building was a small block of Yellow[2] brick that contained three stores, one for rent, one an all night restaurant, and the other was a garage Repairs. GEORGE B. WILSON. Cars Bough and Sold
I think the ash is caused by factories that run off of coal.↩︎
The color yellow is a stark contrast to the grey landscape around it. It makes it standout, like the sun peeking through the clouds.↩︎
item.guid: Plot Points and Scenes/Valley of Ashes.md

item.title: Repairs. GEORGE B. WILSON. Cars Bough and Sold
item.description:
Locations
owned by George B. Wilson The interior was unprosperous and bare The only car visible was the dust covered wreck of a Ford
Tom brings Nick to meet Tom's girl in New York
Tom's girl is George B. Wilson's wife Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle)
Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle) is wearing a dark Blue crepe-de-chine [1]
Tom tells Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle) to meet him by the news stand on the lower level while George B. Wilson went to go get some chairs
Dark blue suggests strength and sturdiness↩︎
item.guid: Locations/Repairs. GEORGE B. WILSON. Cars Bough and Sold.md

item.title: Senior Society
item.description:
Nick and Tom were in the senior society together pg.18 [1]
Most likely a Senior Society from New Haven↩︎

item.title: The First Telephone Call
item.description:
The Butler answers the telephone then walks over to tom and murmurs something to him
Nick tries to talk to Miss Baker but she shushes him.
Miss Baker was trying to eaves drop on Tom's phonecall pg. 29 [1]
Nick tries to tell Miss Baker that Mr. Gatsby is his neighbor
Miss Baker tell Nick about "Tom's woman in New York."
Tom returns to the table and asks Nick to meet him at The Stables
Miss Baker wants to eavesdrop and doesn't care about being polite or hiding it. It seems that Nick doesn't want to eavesdrop and wants to give Tom and Daisy some privacy.↩︎
item.guid: Plot Points and Scenes/The First Telephone Call.md

item.title: Nick's first look at Gatsby
item.description: Nick first see's Mr. Gatsby after driving home from the Dinner Scene. Mr. Gatsby was standing infront of Gatsby's Mansion with his hands in his pockets under the Silver pepper of the stars. Mr. Gatsby looked like he was shaking. Nick looked away out to sea and spotted a green light. When Nick looked back Mr. Gatsby was gone. pg. 37
item.guid: Plot Points and Scenes/Nick's first look at Gatsby.md

item.title: Dinner Scene
item.description:
The Buchanans invite Nick over for dinner
on a rosy colored porch red[1]
daisy's knuckle on her little finger turned Black[2] and Blue[3]. "You did it, Tom," she said accusingly pg. 25 Tom Causing Harm
reveals that Daisy married Tom
Daisy and Miss Baker sometimes talk over each other, "unobtrusively, and with a bantering inconsequence that wad never quite chatter, that was as cool as their White[4] dresses" pg. 25
"sharply different from the West(West Egg) where an evening was hurried from phase to phase toward its close" "continually disappointed anticipation" "sheer nervous dread" pg. 26[5]
Daisy makes Nick feel uncivilized pg. 26
Tom mention's the book The Rise of the Coloured Empires[6]
Miss Baker mention's going to Chicago
The First Telephone Call starts to ring and The Butler goes to get it
Daisy talks about The Butler's Nose
Nick reminds Daisy of an absolute rose(Red)[7]
luxury, wealth, power↩︎
Decay, damaged↩︎
Unnatural, swollen↩︎
Pure, clean↩︎
Nick was use to an evening being hurried along and waiting for it to end. In East Egg the people let the night continue until they have to stop.↩︎
Possible racism, "Great Replacement Theory"↩︎
Lovely, delicate↩︎

item.title: Tom Causing Harm
item.description: Tom

item.title: Buchanan's Mansion
item.description:
Locations
The Buchanans live here
Located in East Egg
Red[1] and white[2] Georgian Colonial mansion
French windows in glowing with reflective Gold[3] pg.18
"the windows were ajar and gleaming White[4] against the fresh grass outside" pg. 19
"We walked through a high hallway into a bright rosy-colored(Red)[5] space," pg. 19
"the crimson(Red)[6] room bloomed with light." pg. 33
White[7] dresses worn by Daisy and Miss Baker on pg. 20
The red portions of the mansion could symbolize strength and permanence ↩︎
The white portions of the mansion could symbolize wealth and purity↩︎
Gold represents wealth↩︎
Purity↩︎
Luxury, warmth hospitality↩︎
Luxury, power, status↩︎
Clean, pure↩︎

Italian Child
Taxi ride
Mrs. Wilson's Apartment

item.title: Taxi ride
item.description:
Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle) changes into Mrs. Wilson's Brown Dress lets four taxi cabs drive away before picking one Lavender-colored with Grey upholstery. They pass by a man selling dogs. Mrs. Wilson (Myrtle) wants to get a dog for Mrs. Wilson's apartment. Tom buys Mrs. Wilson's Dog
They drove over to Fifth avenue, Nick claims it to be "so warm and soft, almost pastoral, on the summer Sunday afternoon that (he) wouldn't have been surprised to see a great flock of White sheep turn the corner."

item.title: Daisy
item.description:
Characters
Lives in East Egg with the other The Buchanans
Nick is Daisy's cousin Has a low, thrilling voice pg. 21 "I've heard it said that Daisy's murmur was only to make people lean toward her; and irrelevant criticism that made it no less charming." pg. 21
She is married to Tom pg. 25 Claims she cynical about everything pg. 31
